Data they analyzed from more than 33,000 American children showed that the older the man when a child is conceived, the lower a child’s score is likely to be on tests of concentration, memory, reasoning and reading skills, at least through age 7.

abstract: Residents of Fargo will resume sandbagging along the swollen Red River to prepare for a second crest expected in the next 10 days.
snippet: Residents of Fargo will resume sandbagging along the swollen Red River to prepare for a second crest expected in the next 10 days.
lead_paragraph: Residents of Fargo will resume sandbagging along the swollen Red River to prepare for a second crest expected in the next 10 days. City officials are asking for volunteers to help make sandbags and hope to increase their inventory to 500,000 sandbags to be used to shore up dikes and fill leaks. The National Weather Service is forecasting that the Red River will crest again at Fargo between 38 and 40 feet. That is expected to occur April 16, 17 or 18. Last month, the river crested just shy of 41 feet, and Fargo and neighboring Moorhead, Minn., largely escaped damage after a huge sandbagging effort that raised their dike protection to 43 feet.

headline.main: North Dakota: Sandbags Needed
headline.print_headline: North Dakota: Sandbags Needed

abstract: Federal prosecutors in St. Louis have charged a Canadian flight student with piloting a stolen plane into the United States in what they say was a suicide attempt.
snippet: Federal prosecutors in St. Louis have charged a Canadian flight student with piloting a stolen plane into the United States in what they say was a suicide attempt.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors in St. Louis have charged a Canadian flight student with piloting a stolen plane into the United States in what they say was a suicide attempt. The pilot, Adam D. Leon, 31, was charged with transportation of stolen property and illegal entry. According to the federal complaint, Mr. Leon said he flew the plane into the United States expecting to be shot down by military aircraft. The complaint said Mr. Leon told the authorities he was recently being treated by a psychiatrist. The authorities say Mr. Leon flew the plane for six hours Monday before landing it on a rural Missouri road when it started to run out of fuel. He was trailed along the way by military jets.

headline.main: Missouri: Pilot Faces Charges
headline.print_headline: Missouri: Pilot Faces Charges

abstract: The authorities say a man claiming to be an illegal immigrant ran naked down a Port St. Lucie street so he would be sent back to Mexico.

lead_paragraph: The authorities say a man claiming to be an illegal immigrant ran naked down a Port St. Lucie street so he would be sent back to Mexico. The police responded to a home Saturday night where they say Roberto Carlos, 28, was arguing with his boyfriend. Officers told Mr. Carlos, who appeared to be intoxicated, that he should go home for the evening, but Mr. Carlos told them he wanted to go to jail because he was an illegal immigrant and wanted to go back to Mexico. He then said he planned to punch an officer to get arrested but decided not to after the police told him it would not be in his best interest to do so. That was when he took off his clothes and ran down the street. He was charged with indecent exposure and was being held for immigration officials.

headline.main: Florida: Streaking for a Cause

abstract: The state’s public defender system is facing a lawsuit that seeks to halt prosecutions in hundreds of northeast Georgia cases until lawyers are provided to represent the defendants.
snippet: The state’s public defender system is facing a lawsuit that seeks to halt prosecutions in hundreds of northeast Georgia cases until lawyers are provided to represent the defendants.
lead_paragraph: The state’s struggling public defender system is facing a lawsuit that seeks to halt prosecutions in hundreds of northeast Georgia cases until lawyers are provided to represent the defendants. It is one of the stiffest legal challenges yet to the system, which has lost support from powerful state legislators and faces mounting financial problems amid the economic downturn. The lawsuit, filed in Elbert County Superior Court, contends that about 300 defendants who cannot afford their own lawyers are “left to languish in jail” because they are not provided legal counsel. Some have been without lawyers for six months, said the suit, which was filed by the Southern Center for Human Rights, which is based in Atlanta.

headline.main: Georgia: Defender System Sued
headline.print_headline: Georgia: Defender System Sued

abstract: The A.F.L.-C.I.O, the Change to Win federation and the National Education Association announced that they had created a committee to coordinate positions and act jointly on national issues.
snippet: The A.F.L.-C.I.O, the Change to Win federation and the National Education Association announced that they had created a committee to coordinate positions and act jointly on national issues.
lead_paragraph: The A.F.L.-C.I.O, the Change to Win federation and the National Education Association announced that they had created the National Labor Coordinating Committee to coordinate positions and act jointly on important national issues, like stimulating the economy. The committee will also continue the talks in which seven unions that quit the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and formed the rival Change to Win federation in 2005 are negotiating terms to form a reunited labor federation. David Bonior, the former House Democratic whip, was chosen chairman of the new group. Mr. Bonior said the unity talks made major progress this week in reaching agreement about how a united federation would handle organizing, politics and legislative matters. He said financial and governance issues must still be worked out. “The American labor movement must unify to restore the American dream for working families,” Mr. Bonior said.

headline.main: Unions in Coordinating Group
headline.print_headline: Unions in Coordinating Group

abstract: A man suspected of shooting and killing his estranged wife and three others in rural north Alabama apparently took his own life as well, the authorities said.

lead_paragraph: A man suspected of shooting and killing his estranged wife and three others in rural north Alabama apparently took his own life as well, the authorities said. Travis Clemmons, chief investigator for the Lauderdale County Sheriff’s Office, said the body of Kevin Garner was found near his home in Priceville, which burned to the ground overnight. He said that Mr. Garner apparently killed himself and that a weapon was recovered. Mr. Clemmons said the bodies of Mr. Garner’s estranged wife, Tammy; their 16-year-old daughter; his sister; and his sister’s 11-year-old son were found earlier in a home in Green Hill, above, a small community near the Tennessee line in a nearby county. The Garners were in divorce proceedings with the trial set for Wednesday morning.

abstract: Three Pittsburgh police officers killed while answering a call about a woman fighting with her son did not know that the man had weapons, but a 911 operator did.
snippet: Three Pittsburgh police officers killed while answering a call about a woman fighting with her son did not know that the man had weapons, but a 911 operator did.
lead_paragraph: Three Pittsburgh police officers killed while answering a call about a woman fighting with her son did not know that the man had weapons, but a 911 operator did. She just failed to tell anyone. The operator, who was hired in November, should have asked for more information and did not relay even the basic information she had to police dispatchers, the official in charge of county dispatchers said. She is now on paid administrative leave and is receiving counseling because supervisors are concerned about her well-being. Robert Full, Allegheny County chief of emergency services, said the 911 operator was too distraught to be interviewed, so officials do not fully understand why she did not press for more information about the guns. “If we were told there were weapons in the house, we should have told that to the police officers,” Mr. Full said.

headline.main: Pennsylvania: 911 Operator Didn’t Tell Officers About Guns

abstract: A youthful-looking sex offender who posed as a 12-year-old boy to enroll in several Arizona schools was sentenced to more than 70 years in prison.
snippet: A youthful-looking sex offender who posed as a 12-year-old boy to enroll in several Arizona schools was sentenced to more than 70 years in prison.
lead_paragraph: A youthful-looking sex offender who posed as a 12-year-old boy to enroll in several Arizona schools was sentenced to more than 70 years in prison. The man, Neil H. Rodreick II, 31, pleaded guilty last year to seven criminal charges. Most involved child pornography, but two stemmed from the charade he pulled off for two years. Mr. Rodreick attended schools in Payson, Prescott Valley and Surprise starting in 2005. The authorities said he shaved and wore makeup to help him appear younger, convincing teachers, students and administrators that he was a boy named Casey. He was caught in January 2007 after spending a day in the seventh grade at a Chino Valley school when school officials became suspicious because his birth certificate and other documents looked forged. They had initially thought they might be dealing with a child who had been abducted.

abstract: In her new book, author and blogger Dawn Meehan shows why she has become a beacon for parents who want to be reminded that laughter is the most important tool for raising children.
snippet: In her new book, author and blogger Dawn Meehan shows why she has become a beacon for parents who want to be reminded that laughter is the most important tool for raising children.
lead_paragraph: One day, two of Dawn Meehan’s many children decided to play baseball in the house. That led to a broken light fixture, which Dawn began to sweep up, but she was distracted by shouts that her daughter had tried to flush a pull-up diaper, causing the bathroom to flood. Over the next few hours, all before she’d had time for a cup of coffee, Dawn ran from one half-solved problem to the next: yogurt smeared on the television, an escaped hermit crab in the toy pile, a baby covered in maple syrup, crayon on the living room walls, a three-year-old eating puppy chow, a hole knocked into the bathroom wall.

headline.main: Laughter as a Parenting Tool

abstract: “Cover your mouth when you sneeze,” is an often-repeated parental phrase — the question is, cover it with what?

lead_paragraph: “Cover your mouth when you sneeze.” That’s high on the list of sentences a parent says at least a million times before a child turns five (and then several million more times after that.) “Cover your mouth when you cough,” is on that list too. And with coughing, sneezing and swine very much on our minds right now, it’s an instruction that bears repeating.
